title: So, Riot, what is it that you gain by catering to trolls and ragers?
body: Since you are far more harsh on people who can't take the garbage community anymore and leave games than you are on the people who act like complete sociopaths and cause the problem in the first place, could you explain to me what it is that makes those players so much more important than reasonable people?

replies.body: Technically leaving a game because of your teammate is a pretty troll/rage move tbh

Knucklefist, you're completely ignoring what Eleshakai is trying to tell you.  You are responsible only for your behavior.  You don't 'coddle' or 'kiss-ass' in games, but that doesn't mean acting like a jerk if someone isn't playing well.  Why do you equate 'expressing yourself' with harassing your teammates?  You can express yourself by yelling at the computer or pounding a pillow or something and guess what?  *You won't get in trouble for it*.

If someone else is being a jerk, how does responding in kind help anything?  Instead of one person making the game unpleasent, there are two.  Instead of one person risking full access to their account, there are two.

My advice?  Instead of watching for every little thing your teammates do wrong, try watching for what they do *right*.  Say thank you when the Jungler comes in to gank or if the Support sacrifices themself to let you escape and deny the enemy the gold from ending your kill streak.  Tell your ADC good job when they knock down a tower or the Assassin who takes down that fleeing enemy before he can escape.

Be the better person.  It's not that hard.

> [{quoted}](name=InsaneSamurai,realm=NA,application-id=cIfEodbz,discussion-id=rGq3J7aF,comment-id=00000000000000010001,timestamp=2014-12-28T18:58:57.991+0000)
> I have theories on why it's been this bad for a couple of years for me and seemingly not at all for others

The most likely reason for this is a combination of Confirmation Bias and Negativity Bias. Combined, they can summarize to "Remembering games in a negative light has led you to believe that most people are negative, and since that's what you're looking for, that's what you tend to find."

There's a couple of reasons for that. Eleshakai has noted one of them: people tend to react to how they are viewed, whether they recognize it consciously or unconsciously. As such, seeing people in a negative light *more often* leads them to fulfilling those expectations.

The other reason is more personal: when you expect people to act negatively, you will tend to *only* remember negative actions. You genuinely *won't recognize* other behaviors, or will attribute them to wholly created negative motives. This is the basis of the confirmation bias: people tend to look for evidence that supports their beliefs and *ignore* that which doesn't.

And the thing is, *everyone* does it, and it applies to *any* viewpoint. Players who don't see a lot of trolls? They're seeing the same players you are, they're just seeing them in a different light. Instead of "That guy was a douchebag, who just wanted to ruin my game. What an ass," they think "Man, he's having a rough game. That sucks."

And later on, when you're remembering what a jerk the guy was and how he trolled your game, they don't remember him at all, except as part of "that game where people were having some trouble and we lost."

Actually it's quite the contrary.  I'm pretty sure Negativity Bias(while certainly a real thing) is mainly just an excuse Riot uses to defend the community instead of actually police things or do some research on how toxic people really are.

Most of my post referred to Confirmation Bias, rather than Negativity Bias.

To clarify each (just in case): Negativity Bias is the tendency to remember *negative* experiences more clearly than *positive* experiences (and thus assign greater weight to them), while Confirmation Bias is the tendency to cling to evidence that supports a claim or belief, while ignoring or dismissing evidence that contradicts that claim or belief.

The reality of the overall situation is probably somewhere between your experiences and those of players like myself and Eleshakai. It's almost certain that many of the players you view as trolls were genuinely trying their best. And it's just as certain that many of the players we may view as merely having a bad game were genuinely trolling. Like I said, Confirmation Bias works both ways.

---

Consider this: Riot has full chat logs of every game played for the past few years (and it's not unreasonable that they have chat logs for every game **ever** played). These logs include pre-game, in-game, and post-game.

Riot has *data* from all of those games as well, and are capable of viewing the overall game state in a string of "snapshots," taken about 5s apart (possibly less).

There's no need for them to try such a biased experiment as you indicate above, because they have *way* more data than that could possibly offer. And that data doesn't risk built-in bias in data-collection.

A while back, Lyte actually ran a quick poll of the posting playerbase by opening a thread, inviting people to talk about how toxic their last 10 games were, and then he would post what was actually going on in those games.

What he found was that *most* people didn't run into nearly as many players who were actually considered toxic as they might have expected - though it's important to note that that doesn't mean they weren't expressing toxic behavior, merely that toxic behavior was *uncommon* for them.

The point, because it wasn't even remotely scientific - way too many biases in the data - was to demonstrate how the Negativity Bias can change the way we view a game, and the players in it.

It's also notable that Lyte got his start as a researcher, which makes this a dream job for him, because the amount of data available to him is *ridiculous*. In a real sense, all he does is research toxicity in games, and what affects it. From his perspective, it's easy to see every system Riot develops and examines as a new experiment, showing more data.

Some of what their research has shown is that some 78% of all toxicity demonstrated in games comes from the players who are categorized as "good," and who make up 77% of the overall population. There's so much more related to that. If you haven't yet, I highly recommend [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nbYQ0AVVBGU), recording his Play Nice talk at MIT. It's fascinating.

Of course, since trolls get banned same as ragers, and since - as OP notes in his main post - AFKs get punished *at least* as quickly, your point falls apart very quickly. This isn't about me supporting afks or trolls. It's about not accepting people acting like jerks because of it.

Trolling people is wrong. Randomly raging at people is also wrong. Leaving games is harmful to the other players, and that's wrong. Yelling at people for any of those things is *also* wrong. In fact, in another post (or another draft of one of these, I forget), I said this: "If a genuine troll is going to troll you, he's going to troll you, and nothing you can say is going to change that."

However, there are times when we can *influence* the people around us into worse reactions. That doesn't mean that the guy who decided you were a jerk and started feeding was *right*... he's absolutely in the wrong. But it also doesn't mean it's okay for you to bitch at him for doing so.

And yes. Obviously, negative attitudes can come from being involved in negative situations. Toxicity spreads, from one person to another... but generally? Those players *aren't toxic players*. They're people having a bad day, or who just had a bad game where they got bashed on, or dealing with a string of afks. They're not nasty by nature, they're just on a hair trigger.

a) I'm not ignoring anything. Toxicity is being addressed, in *all* its forms. Some more effectively than others, but systems are being built to address those as well.

b) I have yet to deny the frustration that comes from these situations. I've experienced it myself, and I approach it from a position of sympathy. It *sucks* to be put in that position. But responding to toxicity with **more toxicity** isn't helpful. It's just feeding the cycle.

c) I genuinely don't understand how you think I'm blaming anyone for anything. All I've done so far is explain how Negativity Bias and Confirmation Bias can combine, in the context of the game, to lead us to see toxicity that may not exist, which in turn can lead us to becoming toxic ourselves. It's a nasty, destructive cycle, and I've done it myself. I still catch myself falling into it now and then, and force myself to stop playing.

But if most toxicity comes from players who are caught in that cycle, who are just having a bad day or a string of bad games, there's nothing *I* can personally do about it, except to try to help people recognize the cycle itself, so that they can learn to avoid it.

To my mind, that's not victim blaming. I see it as empowering them to take the steps to change their own situation.

Snarkiness aside, letting someone know they are being an asshole is something we do in real life.  You assumed I meant wandering around and belittling, but that isn't what I said.  I also wouldn't recommend allowing people to talk to you however they want.  The truth is somewhere in the middle, though your self-righteousness is noted.

I think the difference in opinion more lies with what is a 'valid complaint'. I don't think the victimization is valid. Comparing rape victims to someone who insults others for their performance online is not a valid comparison and it leads to exaggerated complaints. I will clear it up for you though:

Case 1: Rape victim accused of 'asking for it' by their clothing: A person who did absolutely nothing wrong who was attacked, that's a victim.

Case 2: A person who reacts to someone's poor play by making comments that that person takes out of context and overreacts to: The person making the negative comments is not a victim. They did something wrong - during a high-stress situation, they failed to show appropriate tact. This led to the OTHER person doing something wrong by overreacting to it. As Jubbinaut said before, two wrongs do NOT make a right... but it also doesn't make either player a 'victim'. They both did something to incite the behaviour and while, certainly, neither of them deserved the magnitude of what they got, they both played a role in it getting to that point, so neither of them are innocent.

And it's an argument that I think is kind of silly. There are very few things in this world that approach the scale of crime that rape is, so comparing the way people approach it to other infractions usually leads to misrepresenting the situation. To use the above example... the reason things like rape whistles and mace and self defense techniques are valid in that case is because of the severity of the crimes. On the other hand, if you started using mace every time someone yelled at you or did something you dislike(which is essentially the equivalent of trolling/playing poorly), you'd probably be charged with assault before long. It's just not a valid comparison due to the magnitude of the infraction.

Except that it is. If 78% of all witnessed toxicity comes from the *generally positive* members of the community, one has to question **why** those players express that toxicity.

The obvious answer is that they're responding to other toxic players, which makes plenty of sense. But then, if *those* players are most likely not normally toxic, why are *they* being toxic in that game?

Eventually, one starts to recognize that *many* (not all, and not necessarily most) situations that become toxic do so because *both sides* are already expecting toxicity. A neutral statement from one player is viewed as toxic by the other, who reacts negatively, inciting the first into toxicity, and it spirals into an argument that leaves both remembering that terrible jerk.

Sure, there are people that are genuinely toxic. That really are just jerks and trolls. Only an idiot would assume otherwise. But those players are the ones the behavioral systems look for, because they're the ones Riot wants gone. But those players don't actually make up the majority of the toxicity in the game. Though I imagine they are the eventual *source* of a significant amount of it.
